Chad,

I have a cross product experiment up and running. I have used the 
"spikey sphere" of 26 vectors giving 26*26=676 test cases that I 
described.  I assign each test case a max fitness of 1.0, basically I 
compare the network's output with the expected result and total the 
error for the three components (x,y and z). This gives me a value 
between 0 and 3 because my vectors are all length 1.0 and therefore each 
component should be between 0 and 1. I then subtract that error from 3 
and divide by 3 to give a fitness between 0 and 1 - did you get all that :)

One change I did make was to ensure that if the sign of the network's 
output was different to the correct answer then I assigned a fitness of 
0 for that component, this makes sense to me because otherwise an answer 
that is very close to the correct result but of the wrong sign is (I 
think) not really such a good answer - the theory being that we want to 
get the sign right first and then worry about precision afterwards.

Using this scheme my current best after several short searches is 443 
out of a maximum of 676.

So I guess this is in line with your observations - that it's quite a 
deceptively tricky domain. I'll do some longer runs soon and maybe make 
a few tweaks to the fitness evaluation scheme.

Colin.
